body: what does "failed to pass scala test" mean? i guess you didn't change any scala code?
I solved the problem by using `ssh-copy-id username@remote_host` to add the correct ssh key between the hosts.
If you could update the CPU version in drat to the latest build, that would work for me, too. I'm not planning on training with the code, just doing predictions with a pre-trained model.
One potential reason is PTX assemble runtime compile. You may try to change NVCCFLAGS, add -gencode option to generate special code for special hardware arch.

The following code gives segfault:

```
>>> import mxnet as mx
>>> import numpy as np
>>> sym, arg_params, aux_params = mx.model.load_checkpoint('resnet-50', 0)
>>> model = mx.mod.Module(symbol=sym, context=mx.cpu(0))
>>> model.bind(for_training=False, data_shapes=[('data', (1, 3, 300, 400))])
>>> model.set_params(arg_params, aux_params)
>>> model.forward(mx.io.DataBatch(data=[mx.nd.zeros((1,3,300,400))], label=[]), is_train=False)
>>> MKL Build:20161005
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

Thanks for the contribution.
This is something I have been thinking about recently. There are two ways we can do it, one is 
provide_data, provide_data_type, provide_data_layout...

The other is provide_data = [(name, data, type, layout), ... ].
I'm still thinking about which is better
@DCYN We have a lot of examples over time and some of them are outdated. You are more than welcome to contribute fixes for outdated examples.
It is complaining about the kvstore compilation, are you sure you are compiling with it? Can you check if the flag is activated in the logs that appears when compiling?

Many thanks. Let me try to contribute something after mastering it.
Define a `mx.io.DataIter` class, shuffle and split data in `__init__` function
Now that you can get the `shape`, you can define Xavier initialization easily. What Xavier matters is the number of input and output neurons.
It seems the lstm inplace grad addto feature is still missing in the nnvm branch. Is there any agenda to add these features? @piiswrong
Many thanks! Would you please give me further instruction? I really know a little about DataIter.

It's the same issue as https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3108.
Please check https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/make/config.mk#L131 to add caffe/build/lib to LD_LIBRARY_PATH in ~/.bashrc (if OS is linux) or ~/.bash_profile (if MAC OS X).
Then run "source ~/.bashrc" in terminal, problem should be solved.
@HrWangChengdu import mxnet in command line can be fixed, but Pycharm not
This link might help http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33812902/pycharm-cannot-find-library

@thirdwing 

here you are my script for the Rarray data training. i believe i followed the same way as the mnist example to define the R array, the only difference is that mnist is gray scale, so its array format is (28,28,1, length), the cifar-10 is rgb scale, so my array format is (32,32,3,length). but when feed into the train model, the accuracy just cant increase as normal. i already tested this CNN by using the mxnet rec file format, it works very well.
```
library(mxnet)
 setwd("/home/mac/R_Projects/MXnet/CIFAR-10/")

 labels <- read.table("bin/batches.meta.txt")
 train.rgb <- array(0, c(32,32,3,50000))
 train.lab <- c()
 num.images = 10000

 ##-load training data set
 for (f in 1:5) {
   to.read <- file(paste("bin/data_batch_", f, ".bin", sep=""), "rb")
   for(i in 1:num.images) {
     l <- readBin(to.read, integer(), size=1, n=1, endian="big")
     r <- as.integer(readBin(to.read, raw(), size=1, n=1024, endian="big"))
     g <- as.integer(readBin(to.read, raw(), size=1, n=1024, endian="big"))
     b <- as.integer(readBin(to.read, raw(), size=1, n=1024, endian="big"))
     index <- num.images \* (f-1) + i
     train.rgb[1:32,1:32,1,index] <- as.array(matrix(r, ncol=32, byrow = TRUE))
     train.rgb[1:32,1:32,2,index] <- as.array(matrix(g, ncol=32, byrow = TRUE))
     train.rgb[1:32,1:32,3,index] <- as.array(matrix(b, ncol=32, byrow = TRUE))
     train.lab[index] = l+1
   }
   close(to.read)
   remove(l,r,g,b,f,i,index, to.read)
 }

 ##- load test data set
 test.rgb <- array(0, c(32,32,3,10000))
 test.lab <- c()
 to.read <- file("bin/test_batch.bin", "rb")
 for(i in 1:num.images) {
   l <- readBin(to.read, integer(), size=1, n=1, endian="big")
   r <- as.integer(readBin(to.read, raw(), size=1, n=1024, endian="big"))
   g <- as.integer(readBin(to.read, raw(), size=1, n=1024, endian="big"))
   b <- as.integer(readBin(to.read, raw(), size=1, n=1024, endian="big"))
   index <- i
   test.rgb[1:32,1:32,1,index] <- as.array(matrix(r, ncol=32, byrow = TRUE))
   test.rgb[1:32,1:32,2,index] <- as.array(matrix(g, ncol=32, byrow = TRUE))
   test.rgb[1:32,1:32,3,index] <- as.array(matrix(b, ncol=32, byrow = TRUE))
   test.lab[index] = l+1
 }
 close(to.read)
 remove(l,r,g,b,i,index, to.read)

 train <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = train.rgb, label = train.lab, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)
 test <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = test.rgb, label = test.lab, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)

 ##- Define deep learning network, act_type can be relu, sigmoid, softrelu and tanh
 input_data <- mx.symbol.Variable(name = "data")

 ##- stage 1 (32 - 5 + 2*2)/1 + 1 = 32
 conv1 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data = input_data, kernel = c(5, 5), pad = c(2, 2), num_filter = 32, name = "conv1")
 relu1 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = conv1, act_type = "relu",  name = "relu1")
 pool1 <- mx.symbol.Pooling(data = relu1, kernel = c(3, 3), stride = c(2, 2), pool_type = "max", name = "pool1")

 ##- stage 2 (32 -5 + 2*2)/1 + 1 = 32
conv2 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data = pool1, kernel = c(5, 5), pad = c(2, 2), num_filter = 32, name = "conv2")
 relu2 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = conv2, act_type = "relu", name = "relu2")
pool2 <- mx.symbol.Pooling(data = relu2, kernel = c(3, 3), stride = c(2, 2), pool_type = "avg", name = "pool2")

 ##- stage 3 (32 - 5 + 2*2)/1 + 1 = 32
 conv3 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data = pool2, kernel = c(5, 5), pad = c(2, 2), num_filter = 64, name = "conv3")
 relu3 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = conv3, act_type = "relu", name = "relu3")
 pool3 <- mx.symbol.Pooling(data = relu3, kernel = c(3, 3), stride = c(2, 2), pool_type = "avg", name = "pool3")

 ##- stage 4
 flatten <- mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool3)

 ##- stage 5
 fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = flatten, num_hidden = 64, name = "fc1")
 relu4 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, act_type = "relu", name = "relu4")

 ## stage 6
 fc2 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = relu4, num_hidden = 10, name = "fc2")
 softmax <- mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc2, name = 'softmax')

 mx.set.seed(0)
 device.gpu <- mx.gpu(0)

 model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(softmax,
                                      X=train,
                                      eval.data=test,
                                      ctx=device.gpu, 
                                      num.round=100,
                                      array.batch.size=100,
                                      learning.rate=0.0001,
                                      momentum=0.9,
                                      eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy,
                                      initializer = mx.init.Xavier(factor_type='in', magnitude=2.34),
                                      wd=0.00001,
                                      epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100)
                                      )
```

@piiswrong

Good question: you are correct, by default, its the identity op. The reason for this strange looking design: it brings consistency with the other sequence ops (`SequenceLast` and `SequenceReverse`) which often just want to be used without specifying sequence lengths. 

Honestly, I'm leaning towards requiring sequence length the default behaviour for all these ops. Not sure if its too late to change the behaviour.

It seems more suitable to move the implementation of padding to the MShadow side. What do you think? @sbodenstein @piiswrong
Yes, the scala-package is now using scala 2.11.

Need to be a bit careful on this. since this is an convention issue. On some of the axis related ops, e.g. sum, negative axis is used to represent sum over all. I feel in general we need something like axis=None to replace that convention. 

Better note this convention in a issue, and keep the direction right

The problem is this add argument to the interface and will break custom modules whose bind() doesn't accept input_types.

A possible solution is to use a class (instead of tuple) for data_shapes.
like

```
class DataDesc(namedtuple(['name', 'shape'])):
   def __new__(cls, name, shape, type=mx_real_t, layout='NCHW'):
      ret = __super(DataDesc, cls).__init__(name, shape)
      ret.type = type
      ret.layout = layout
      return ret
```

This way we can add more info to data_shapes tuple without breaking exsiting code

you can debug with examples/python-howto/monitor_weight.py
